whether 1993 guidelines or 1995 rules applied. application to tribunal lodged when 1993 guidelines in force. those guidelines applicable. consideration of 1995 rules. 1995 rules considered. national health act 1953 national health amendment act 1955 pharmaceutical benefits determination no pb 9 of 1993 pharmaceutical benefits determination no pb 6 of 1995 esber v the commonwealth of australia [1992] hca 20 ; 174 clr 430 patti-mae lee v secretary department of social security (unreported federal court judgment full court no 960677) smoker v pharmacy restructuring authority and ors [1994] fca 1487 ; 53 fcr 287 re hargreaves and australian community pharmacy authority 38 ald 679 re khan and australian community pharmacy authority and anor (unreported tribunal decision no 10871) re teys and ors and australian community pharmacy authority and anor 41 ald 689 pharmacy restructuring authority and anor v chatfield [1993] fca 348 ; 18 aar 34 re hargreaves and australian community pharmacy authority (no 2) [1995] aata 326 ; 41 ald 147 secretary, department of health, housing, local government and community services and anor v kaderbhai and anor [1994] fca 1197 ; 122 alr 577 hearing sydney, 19-21 august 1996 18:10:1996 counsel for the applicant: mr j.a. trebeck solicitor for applicant: herbert weller counsel for the respondent: mr r. beech-jones solicitor for the respondent: australian government solicitor order 1. the decisions under review in matter no n95/154 are set aside and this matter remitted to the respondent with the following directions, namely:

(a) the australian community pharmacy authority is to recommend to the secretary, department of health and family services that the applicants' application for the establishment of a pharmacy at glossodia shopping village, golden valley road, glossadia be approved; and (b) the secretary, department of health and family services is to reconsider the said application in the light of the above substituted recommendation.

citances.sentence:
Section 10 of the Rules is mandatory. It says that unless the prescribed requirements have been satisfied, "the Authority must recommend that an Applicant not be approved". The Rule gives the Authority no discretion to recommend that an Applicant be approved if the prescribed requirements have not been met. [1] Relevantly for this decision, the applicable criteria are those prescribed under subsection 9(b) and Item 114 of Part 2 of Schedule 1. Pursuant to Item 114 of the Rules, the proposed premises must be in a rural locality and at least 10km, by the shortest lawful access route, from the nearest approved premises. In essence, the High Court in Shi held that there is nothing in the Tribunal's enabling legislation that confines it to the facts and circumstances before the primary-decision maker. The exception to this general principle is that, if the statute under which the decision under review was made limits the review to the particular time in the past, then the Tribunal will similarly be limited to the state of affairs existing at that relevant time. [2] Kiefel J stated in Shi at [142]:
In considering what is the right decision, the tribunal must address the same question as the original decision-maker was required to address. Identifying the question raised by the statute for decision will usually determine the facts which may be taken into account in connection with the decision. The issue is then one of relevance, determined by reference to the elements in the question, or questions, necessary to be addressed in reaching a decision.
